title: 114_hr2332
content:
The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes the Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under the Secretary of Transportation. Grants can be awarded on a competitive basis to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects determined by the Secretary. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects determined by the Secretary of Transportation, including highway, bridge, and public transportation projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects determined by the Secretary of Transportation, including highway, bridge, public transportation, passenger or freight rail transportation, and port infrastructure investments. This includes projects that expedite completion, connect ports to other modes of transportation, and improve freight movement efficiency. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects, including aviation and water projects. The Secretary of Transportation coordinates grants with the EPA and Army for water projects. Eligibility for grants requires specific criteria outlined in the application process. The Act establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects, including aviation and water projects. Entities meeting specific criteria must submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations for grant criteria within 90 days. Financial commitments will be considered in the criteria. The Secretary will establish criteria for grant consideration, including financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants will be awarded based on specific considerations outlined by the Secretary. The Secretary will ensure equitable distribution of grants, address urban and rural needs, promote veteran training and employment, and allocate a percentage of grant amounts to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Each project funded by a grant under this Act must comply with Title 40 requirements and Buy America provisions, ensuring that all iron, steel, and manufactured goods used are produced in the United States, with exceptions allowed by the Secretary. The Secretary may allow exceptions to Buy America provisions if it is inconsistent with the public interest, if the required goods are not produced in the US in sufficient quantities or quality, or if including US-produced goods increases project costs by more than 25 percent. Justifications must be provided by the Secretary. The Secretary may waive Buy America provisions if necessary, with detailed justification required. International agreements must be considered. Transparency and accountability are emphasized in grant utilization. The Secretary must ensure grants are used efficiently, provide public information on grants, and report to Congress annually. Coordination with other federal departments is required for environmental streamlining. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to appropriate $985 billion for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020. 85% of the funds will be used to make grants for eligible projects. 85% of the $985 billion authorized for grants from 2016 to 2020 will be used for projects in subsections (A), (B), (C), (D), (E), and (F) of subsection (c)(1). The Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary is authorized to issue bonds for the initiative, with a maximum total face value of $300 billion, subject to specific terms and conditions. The Secretary of the Treasury will make bond proceeds available to the Secretary of Transportation for the program established under section 2(a) of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORT.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Transportation must provide Congress with a detailed report on the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
